title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.16 | 18-01-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya Chakshuran Militam Yena Tasmait Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, offering obeisances to the spiritual master and Lord Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Pariksit heard that out of his causeless mercy Lord Krishna, or Vishnu, who is universally obeyed, rendered all kinds of service to the malleable sons of Pandu
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 16th verse of the 16th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining how Lord Krishna, despite being supreme, served the Pandavas, inspiring devotion in Maharaj Pariksit.

segments.key_quote: When somebody performs bhakti for some material benefit, then such bhakti is called materially contaminated bhakti.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the concept of pure devotion (unalloyed bhakti) versus devotion contaminated by material desires, emphasizing that true bhakti aims to awaken love for Krishna and purify oneself.

segments.key_quote: Similarly, when we say bhakti in the scriptures, when it is said bhakti, it means pure devotion. 100% devotion to Krishna.
segments.summary: Using the analogy of gold purity (carats), the speaker explains that pure devotion is free from any material desires and is 100% dedicated to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Simply to please Krishna by one's service. That's all.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the sole purpose of rendering devotional service to Krishna is to please Him, as exemplified by the pure devotion of the Pandavas.

segments.key_quote: In their intimate relationship, devotees forget Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the intimate relationship between devotees and Krishna, where devotees sometimes forget Krishna's supreme position, allowing for deeper loving service, using the examples of Arjuna and Mother Yashoda.

segments.key_quote: The servant is the master. The master is the servant. There is no difference.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the concept of reciprocity between Krishna and His devotees, where Krishna also serves His devotees to please them, highlighting that the relationship is not like a material master-servant dynamic, using the example of Krishna as Arjuna's chariot driver.

segments.key_quote: Krishna acted as a night watchman for the Pandavas, because they were exiled.
segments.summary: The speaker describes how Maharaj Pariksit was overwhelmed by Krishna's kindness and willingness to do anything for His devotees, such as acting as a night watchman for the Pandavas, leading to tears of love and ecstasy.

segments.key_quote: Hearing about Krishna's activities itself is devotional service. It is completely a transcendental activity. And it purifies us and makes us eligible to go back, come back to God.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing that Krishna's dealings with His devotees are transcendental and free from material contamination, and that hearing about these activities is a form of devotional service that purifies and leads one back to God.
